types.name: AlleleMatrix
types.description: The AlleleMatrix object is used to describe a matrix of genotyping results. This 2d array of data reduces the overall size of the response for larger datasets, when compared to the Calls endpoints. This makes genotype data retrieval faster and easier.

fields.name: callSets
fields.description: A list of unique identifiers for the CallSets contained in the matrix response. This array should match the ordering for columns in the matrix. A CallSet is a unique combination of a Sample and a sequencing event. CallSets often have a 1-to-1 relationship with Samples, but this is not always the case.

fields.name: dataMatrices
fields.description: The 'dataMatrices' are an array of matrix objects that hold the allele data and associated metadata. Each matrix should be the same size and orientation, aligned with the "callSetDbIds" as columns and the "variantDbIds" as rows.

fields.name: expandHomozygotes
fields.description: Should homozygotes be expanded (true) or collapsed into a single occurrence (false)

fields.name: pagination
fields.description: Pagination for the matrix

fields.name: sepPhased
fields.description: The string used as a separator for phased allele calls.

fields.name: sepUnphased
fields.description: The string used as a separator for unphased allele calls.

fields.name: unknownString
fields.description: The string used as a representation for missing data.

fields.name: variantSets
fields.description: A list of unique identifiers for the VariantSets contained in the matrix response. A VariantSet is a data set originating from a sequencing event. Often, users will only be interested in data from a single VariantSet, but in some cases a user might be interested in a matrix with data from multiple VariantSets.

fields.name: variants
fields.description: A list of unique identifiers for the Variants contained in the matrix response. This array should match the ordering for rows in the matrix.

fields.description: 2 letter ISO 639-1 code for the language of submission of the variable.

fields.name: methodDbIds
fields.description:
A description of the way an Observation should be collected.
For example, an ObservationVariable might be defined with a Trait of "plant height", a Scale of "meters", and a Method of "tape measure". This variable would be distinct from a variable with the Method "estimation" or "drone image processing".

fields.name: ontologyReference
fields.description:
MIAPPE V1.1

(DM-85) Variable accession number - Accession number of the variable in the Crop Ontology

(DM-87) Trait accession number - Accession number of the trait in a suitable controlled vocabulary (Crop Ontology, Trait Ontology).

(DM-89) Method accession number - Accession number of the method in a suitable controlled vocabulary (Crop Ontology, Trait Ontology).

(DM-93) Scale accession number - Accession number of the scale in a suitable controlled vocabulary (Crop Ontology).

fields.name: scaleDbIds
fields.description:
A Scale describes the units and acceptable values for an ObservationVariable.
For example, an ObservationVariable might be defined with a Trait of "plant height", a Scale of "meters", and a Method of "tape measure". This variable would be distinct from a variable with the Scale "inches" or "pixels".

fields.name: scientist
fields.description: Name of scientist submitting the variable.

fields.name: status
fields.description: Variable status. (examples: "recommended", "obsolete", "legacy", etc.)

fields.name: submissionTimestamp
fields.description: Timestamp when the Variable was added (ISO 8601)

fields.name: synonyms
fields.description: Other variable names

fields.name: traitDbIds
fields.description:
A Trait describes what property is being observed.
For example, an ObservationVariable might be defined with a Trait of "plant height", a Scale of "meters", and a Method of "tape measure". This variable would be distinct from a variable with the Trait "Leaf length" or "Flower height".

types.name: BiologicalStatusOfAccessionCode
types.description:
MCPD (v2.1) (SAMPSTAT) 19. The coding scheme proposed can be used at 3 different levels of detail: either by using the general codes such as 100, 200, 300, 400, or by using the more specific codes such as 110, 120, etc. 

100) Wild 
110) Natural 
120) Semi-natural/wild 
130) Semi-natural/sown 
200) Weedy 
300) Traditional cultivar/landrace 
400) Breeding/research material 
410) Breeders line 
411) Synthetic population 
412) Hybrid 
413) Founder stock/base population 
414) Inbred line (parent of hybrid cultivar) 
415) Segregating population 
416) Clonal selection 
420) Genetic stock 
421) Mutant (e.g. induced/insertion mutants, tilling populations) 
422) Cytogenetic stocks (e.g. chromosome addition/substitution, aneuploids,  amphiploids) 
423) Other genetic stocks (e.g. mapping populations) 
500) Advanced or improved cultivar (conventional breeding methods) 
600) GMO (by genetic engineering) 
999) Other (Elaborate in REMARKS field)

types.name: Call
types.description:
A `Call` represents the determination of genotype with respect to a particular `Variant`. 

It may include associated information such as quality and phasing. For example, a call might assign a probability of 0.32 to the occurrence of a SNP named RS_1234 in a call set with the name NA_12345.

fields.name: additionalInfo
fields.description: A free space containing any additional information related to a particular object. A data source may provide any JSON object, unrestricted by the BrAPI specification.

fields.name: callSetDbIds
fields.description:
The ID of the call set this variant call belongs to.

If this field is not present, the ordering of the call sets from a `SearchCallSetsRequest` over this `VariantSet` is guaranteed to match the ordering of the calls on this `Variant`. The number of results will also be the same.

fields.name: genotypeMetadata
fields.description: Genotype Metadata are additional layers of metadata associated with each genotype.

fields.name: genotypeValue
fields.description: The value of this genotype call

fields.name: phaseSet
fields.description:
If this field is populated, this variant call's genotype ordering implies the phase of the bases and 
is consistent with any other variant calls on the same contig which have the same phase set string.

fields.name: variantDbIds
fields.description: The ID of the variant this call belongs to.

fields.name: variantSetDbIds
fields.description: The unique identifier for a VariantSet

inputFields.name: commonCropNames
inputFields.description:
The BrAPI Common Crop Name is the simple, generalized, widely accepted name of the organism being researched. It is most often used in multi-crop systems where digital resources need to be divided at a high level. Things like 'Maize', 'Wheat', and 'Rice' are examples of common crop names.

Use this parameter to only return results associated with the given crops. 

Use `GET /commoncropnames` to find the list of available crops on a server.

inputFields.name: programDbIds
inputFields.description:
A BrAPI Program represents the high level organization or group who is responsible for conducting trials and studies. Things like Breeding Programs and Funded Projects are considered BrAPI Programs. 

Use this parameter to only return results associated with the given programs. 

Use `GET /programs` to find the list of available programs on a server.

inputFields.name: programNames

Use `GET /programs` to find the list of available programs on a server.

types.name: ContentMixture
types.description:
The mixture of germplasm present in the seed lot.
If this seed lot only contains a single germplasm, the response should contain the name and DbId of that germplasm with a mixturePercentage value of 100
If the seed lot contains a mixture of different germplasm, the response should contain the name and DbId every germplasm present. The mixturePercentage field should contain the ratio of each germplasm in the total mixture. All of the mixturePercentage values in this array should sum to equal 100.

fields.description: The cross for the germplasm using in this content mixture

fields.name: germplasmDbIds
fields.description: The germplasm using in this content mixture

fields.name: mixturePercentage
fields.description: The percentage of the given germplasm in the seed lot mixture.

fields.name: seedLotDbIds
fields.description: associated seedLot

inputFields.name: commonCropNames
inputFields.description:
The BrAPI Common Crop Name is the simple, generalized, widely accepted name of the organism being researched. It is most often used in multi-crop systems where digital resources need to be divided at a high level. Things like 'Maize', 'Wheat', and 'Rice' are examples of common crop names.

Use this parameter to only return results associated with the given crops. 

Use `GET /commoncropnames` to find the list of available crops on a server.

inputFields.name: programDbIds
inputFields.description:
A BrAPI Program represents the high level organization or group who is responsible for conducting trials and studies. Things like Breeding Programs and Funded Projects are considered BrAPI Programs. 

Use this parameter to only return results associated with the given programs. 

Use `GET /programs` to find the list of available programs on a server.

Use this parameter to only return results associated with the given program names. Program names are not required to be unique.

Use `GET /programs` to find the list of available programs on a server.

types.name: DataMatrix
types.description: A two dimensional array that holds allele data or associated metadata. Each matrix should be the same size and orientation, aligned with the "callSetDbIds" as columns and the "variantDbIds" as rows.

fields.name: dataMatrix
fields.description: The two dimensional array of data, providing the allele matrix or an additional layer of metadata associated with each genotype value. Each matrix should be the same size and orientation, aligned with the "callSetDbIds" as columns and the "variantDbIds" as rows.

fields.name: dataMatrixAbbreviation
fields.description:
The abbreviated code of the field represented in this data matrix. These codes should match the VCF standard when possible and the key word "GT" is reserved for the allele matrix. Examples of other metadata matrices include: "GQ", "RD", and "HQ"
This maps to a FORMAT field in the VCF file standard.

fields.name: dataMatrixName
fields.description:
The name of the field represented in this data matrix. The key word "Genotype" is reserved for the allele matrix. Examples of other metadata matrices include: "Genotype Quality", "Read Depth", and "Haplotype Quality"
This maps to a FORMAT field in the VCF file standard.

fields.name: dataType
fields.description: The type of field represented in this data matrix. This is intended to help parse the data out of JSON.

fields.name: alleleMatrixDbIds
fields.description: Data matrices associated with an alleleMatrix

types.name: Event
types.description:
An event is discrete occurrence at a particular time in the experiment. Events may be the realization of Treatments or parts of Treatments, or may be confounding to Treatments.
ICASA Management Events allow for the following types -> planting, fertilizer, irrigation, tillage, organic_material, harvest, bed_prep, inorg_mulch, inorg_mul_rem, chemicals, mowing, observation, weeding, puddling, flood_level, other

fields.name: additionalInfo
fields.description: A free space containing any additional information related to a particular object. A data source may provide any JSON object, unrestricted by the BrAPI specification.

fields.name: eventDateRange
fields.description: An object describing when a particular Event has taken place. An Event can occur at one or more discrete time points (`discreteDates`) or an event can happen continuously over a longer period of time (`startDate`, `endDate`)

fields.name: eventDbId
fields.description: Internal database identifier

fields.name: eventDescription
fields.description:
A detailed, human-readable description of this event
MIAPPE V1.1 (DM-67) Event description - Description of the event, including details such as amount applied and possibly duration of the event.

fields.name: eventParameters
fields.description: A list of objects describing additional event parameters. Each of the following accepts a human-readable value or URI

fields.name: eventType
fields.description:
An identifier for this event type, in the form of an ontology class reference
ICASA Management events allow for the following types: planting, fertilizer, irrigation, tillage, organic_material, harvest, bed_prep, inorg_mulch, inorg_mul_rem, chemicals, mowing, observation, weeding, puddling, flood_level, other
MIAPPE V1.1 (DM-66) Event accession number - Accession number of the event type in a suitable controlled vocabulary (Crop Ontology).

MIAPPE V1.1 (DM-66) Event accession number - Accession number of the event type in a suitable controlled vocabulary (Crop Ontology).

fields.description: A list of the affected observation units. If this parameter is not given, it is understood that the event affected all units in the study

fields.name: studyDbIds
fields.description: The study in which the event occurred

types.name: EventParameter
types.description: Additional metadata to describe an event, based on the ICASA standard model. For example, 'Tillage Implement' (tiimp), 'Tillage Depth' (tidep), and 'Tillage Mix Effectiveness' (timix) might all be recorded parameters for a Tillage event.

fields.name: code
fields.description:
The shortened code name of an event parameter
ICASA "Code_Display"

fields.name: description
fields.description: A human readable description of this event parameter. This description is usually associated with the 'name' and 'code' of an event parameter.

fields.name: name
fields.description:
The full name of an event parameter
ICASA "Variable_Name"

fields.name: units
fields.description:
The units or data type of the 'value'.
If the 'value' comes from a standardized vocabulary or an encoded list of values, then 'unit' should be 'code'.
If the 'value' IS NOT a number, then 'unit' should specify a data type eg. 'text', 'boolean', 'date', etc.
If the value IS a number, then 'unit' should specify the units used eg. 'ml', 'cm', etc
ICASA "Unit_or_type"

fields.name: value
fields.description: The single value of this event parameter. This single value is accurate for all the dates in the date range. If 'value' is populated then 'valuesByDate' should NOT be populated.

fields.name: valueDescription
fields.description: If the event parameter 'unit' field is 'code', then use 'valueDescription' to add a human readable description to the value.

fields.name: valuesByDate
fields.description: An array of values corresponding to each timestamp in the 'discreteDates' array of this event. The 'valuesByDate' array should exactly match the size of the 'discreteDates' array. If 'valuesByDate' is populated then 'value' should NOT be populated.

fields.name: eventDbIds
fields.description: associated event

inputFields.name: commonCropNames
inputFields.description:
The BrAPI Common Crop Name is the simple, generalized, widely accepted name of the organism being researched. It is most often used in multi-crop systems where digital resources need to be divided at a high level. Things like 'Maize', 'Wheat', and 'Rice' are examples of common crop names.

Use this parameter to only return results associated with the given crops. 

Use `GET /commoncropnames` to find the list of available crops on a server.

inputFields.name: programDbIds
inputFields.description:
A BrAPI Program represents the high level organization or group who is responsible for conducting trials and studies. Things like Breeding Programs and Funded Projects are considered BrAPI Programs. 

Use this parameter to only return results associated with the given programs. 

Use `GET /programs` to find the list of available programs on a server.

inputFields.name: programNames
inputFields.description:
Use this parameter to only return results associated with the given program names. Program names are not required to be unique.

Use `GET /programs` to find the list of available programs on a server.

types.name: GeoJSON
types.description:
One geometry as defined by GeoJSON (RFC 7946). All coordinates are decimal values on the WGS84 geographic coordinate reference system.

Copied from RFC 7946 Section 3.1.1

A position is an array of numbers. There MUST be two or more elements. The first two elements are longitude and latitude, or
easting and northing, precisely in that order and using decimal numbers. Altitude or elevation MAY be included as an optional third element.

types.name: Germplasm
types.description: The conceptual identifiers and metadata describing a genetically unique organism that is noteworthy in some way. Depending on context, a Germplasm might be synonymous with Accession, Line, or Genotype. Note that Germplasm is conceptual data, not necessarily associated to a real physical object, so Seed/Inventory Lots and Observation Units become physical instantiations of a particular Germplasm. Note a Germplasm is unique and noteworthy, so a Cross may or may not create a new Germplasm, since not every Cross is unique or noteworthy.

fields.name: accessionNumber
fields.description:
The unique identifier for a material or germplasm within a genebank

MCPD (v2.1) (ACCENUMB) 2. This is the unique identifier for accessions within a genebank, and is assigned when a sample is entered into the genebank collection (e.g. "PI 113869").

fields.name: acquisitionDate
fields.description:
The date a material or germplasm was acquired by the genebank 

MCPD (v2.1) (ACQDATE) 12. Date on which the accession entered the collection [YYYYMMDD] where YYYY is the year, MM is the month and DD is the day. Missing data (MM or DD) should be indicated with hyphens or "00" [double zero].

fields.name: additionalInfo
fields.description: A free space containing any additional information related to a particular object. A data source may provide any JSON object, unrestricted by the BrAPI specification.

fields.name: biologicalStatusOfAccessionCode
fields.description:
MCPD (v2.1) (SAMPSTAT) 19. The coding scheme proposed can be used at 3 different levels of detail: either by using the general codes such as 100, 200, 300, 400, or by using the more specific codes such as 110, 120, etc. 

100) Wild 
110) Natural 
120) Semi-natural/wild 
130) Semi-natural/sown 
200) Weedy 
300) Traditional cultivar/landrace 
400) Breeding/research material 
410) Breeders line 
411) Synthetic population 
412) Hybrid 
413) Founder stock/base population 
414) Inbred line (parent of hybrid cultivar) 
415) Segregating population 
416) Clonal selection 
420) Genetic stock 
421) Mutant (e.g. induced/insertion mutants, tilling populations) 
422) Cytogenetic stocks (e.g. chromosome addition/substitution, aneuploids,  amphiploids) 
423) Other genetic stocks (e.g. mapping populations) 
500) Advanced or improved cultivar (conventional breeding methods) 
600) GMO (by genetic engineering) 
999) Other (Elaborate in REMARKS field)

fields.name: biologicalStatusOfAccessionDescription
fields.description: Supplemental text description for 'biologicalStatusOfAccessionCode'

fields.name: breedingMethodDbIds
fields.description: The unique identifier for the breeding method used to create this germplasm

fields.name: collection
fields.description: A specific panel/collection/population name this germplasm belongs to.

fields.name: commonCropName
fields.description:
Common name for the crop 

MCPD (v2.1) (CROPNAME) 10. Common name of the crop. Example: "malting barley", "mas".

fields.name: countryOfOriginCode
fields.description:
3-letter ISO 3166-1 code of the country in which the sample was originally collected 

MCPD (v2.1) (ORIGCTY) 13. 3-letter ISO 3166-1 code of the country in which the sample was originally collected (e.g. landrace, crop wild relative, farmers variety), bred or selected (breeding lines, GMOs, segregating populations, hybrids, modern cultivars, etc.). Note- Descriptors 14 to 16 below should be completed accordingly only if it was "collected".

fields.name: defaultDisplayName
fields.description: Human readable name used for display purposes

fields.name: documentationURL
fields.description: A URL to the human readable documentation of an object

fields.name: donors
fields.description: List of donor institutes

fields.name: externalReferences
fields.description: An array of external reference ids. These are references to this piece of data in an external system. Could be a simple string or a URI.

fields.name: genus
fields.description:
Genus name for taxon. Initial uppercase letter required.

MCPD (v2.1) (GENUS) 5. Genus name for taxon. Initial uppercase letter required.

MIAPPE V1.1 (DM-43) Genus - Genus name for the organism under study, according to standard scientific nomenclature.

fields.name: germplasmDbId
fields.description:
The ID which uniquely identifies a germplasm within the given database server
MIAPPE V1.1 (DM-41) Biological material ID - Code used to identify the biological material in the data file. Should be unique within the Investigation. Can correspond to experimental plant ID, inventory lot ID, etc. This material identification is different from a BiosampleID which corresponds to Observation Unit or Samples sections below.

fields.name: germplasmName
fields.description:
Name of the germplasm. It can be the preferred name and does not have to be unique.

MCPD (v2.1) (ACCENAME) 11. Either a registered or other designation given to the material received, other than the donors accession number (23) or collecting number (3). First letter uppercase. Multiple names are separated by a semicolon without space.

fields.name: germplasmOrigin
fields.description: Information for material (orchard, natural sites, ...). Geographic identification of the plants from which seeds or cutting have been taken to produce that germplasm.

fields.name: germplasmPUI
fields.description:
The Permanent Unique Identifier which represents a germplasm

MIAPPE V1.1 (DM-41) Biological material ID - Code used to identify the biological material in the data file. Should be unique within the Investigation. Can correspond to experimental plant ID, inventory lot ID, etc This material identification is different from a BiosampleID which corresponds to Observation Unit or Samples sections below.

MIAPPE V1.1 (DM-51) Material source DOI - Digital Object Identifier (DOI) of the material source

MCPD (v2.1) (PUID) 0. Any persistent, unique identifier assigned to the accession so it can be unambiguously referenced at the global level and the information associated with it harvested through automated means. Report one PUID for each accession. The Secretariat of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture (PGRFA) is facilitating the assignment of a persistent unique identifier (PUID), in the form of a DOI, to PGRFA at the accession level. Genebanks not applying a true PUID to their accessions should use, and request recipients to use, the concatenation of INSTCODE, ACCENUMB, and GENUS as a globally unique identifier similar in most respects to the PUID whenever they exchange information on accessions with third parties.

fields.name: germplasmPreprocessing
fields.description: Description of any process or treatment applied uniformly to the germplasm, prior to the study itself. Can be provided as free text or as an accession number from a suitable controlled vocabulary.

fields.name: instituteCode
fields.description:
The code for the institute that maintains the material. 

MCPD (v2.1) (INSTCODE) 1. FAO WIEWS code of the institute where the accession is maintained. The codes consist of the 3-letter ISO 3166 country code of the country where the institute is located plus a number (e.g. PER001). The current set of institute codes is available from http://www.fao.org/wiews. For those institutes not yet having an FAO Code, or for those with "obsolete" codes, see "Common formatting rules (v)".

fields.name: instituteName
fields.description: The name of the institute that maintains the material

fields.name: pedigree
fields.description:
The cross name and optional selection history.

MCPD (v2.1) (ANCEST) 20. Information about either pedigree or other description of ancestral information (e.g. parent variety in case of mutant or selection). For example a pedigree 'Hanna/7*Atlas//Turk/8*Atlas' or a description 'mutation found in Hanna', 'selection from Irene' or 'cross involving amongst others Hanna and Irene'.

fields.name: seedSource
fields.description:
An identifier for the source of the biological material
MIAPPE V1.1 (DM-50) Material source ID (Holding institute/stock centre, accession) - An identifier for the source of the biological material, in the form of a key-value pair comprising the name/identifier of the repository from which the material was sourced plus the accession number of the repository for that material. Where an accession number has not been assigned, but the material has been derived from the crossing of known accessions, the material can be defined as follows: "mother_accession X father_accession", or, if father is unknown, as "mother_accession X UNKNOWN". For in situ material, the region of provenance may be used when an accession is not available.

fields.name: seedSourceDescription
fields.description:
Description of the material source

MIAPPE V1.1 (DM-56) Material source description - Description of the material source

fields.name: species
fields.description:
Specific epithet portion of the scientific name in lowercase letters.

MCPD (v2.1) (SPECIES) 6. Specific epithet portion of the scientific name in lowercase letters. Only the following abbreviation is allowed: "sp." 

MIAPPE V1.1 (DM-44) Species - Species name (formally: specific epithet) for the organism under study, according to standard scientific nomenclature.

fields.name: speciesAuthority
fields.description:
The authority organization responsible for tracking and maintaining the species name 

MCPD (v2.1) (SPAUTHOR) 7. Provide the authority for the species name.

fields.name: storageTypes
fields.description: The type of storage this germplasm is kept in at a genebank.

fields.name: subtaxa
fields.description:
Subtaxon can be used to store any additional taxonomic identifier.

MCPD (v2.1) (SUBTAXA) 8. Subtaxon can be used to store any additional taxonomic identifier. The following abbreviations are allowed: "subsp." (for subspecies); "convar." (for convariety); "var." (for variety); "f." (for form); "Group" (for "cultivar group").

MIAPPE V1.1 (DM-44) Infraspecific name - Name of any subtaxa level, including variety, crossing name, etc. It can be used to store any additional taxonomic identifier. Either free text description or key-value pair list format (the key is the name of the rank and the value is the value of  the rank). Ranks can be among the following terms: subspecies, cultivar, variety, subvariety, convariety, group, subgroup, hybrid, line, form, subform. For MCPD compliance, the following abbreviations are allowed: subsp. (subspecies); convar. (convariety); var. (variety); f. (form); Group (cultivar group).

fields.name: subtaxaAuthority
fields.description:
The authority organization responsible for tracking and maintaining the subtaxon information

MCPD (v2.1) (SUBTAUTHOR) 9. Provide the subtaxon authority at the most detailed taxonomic level.

fields.name: synonyms
fields.description:
List of alternative names or IDs used to reference this germplasm

MCPD (v2.1) (OTHERNUMB) 24. Any other identifiers known to exist in other collections for this accession. Use the following format: INSTCODE:ACCENUMB;INSTCODE:identifier;INSTCODE and identifier are separated by a colon without space. Pairs of INSTCODE and identifier are separated by a semicolon without space. When the institute is not known, the identifier should be preceded by a colon.

fields.name: taxonIds
fields.description:
The list of IDs for this SPECIES from different sources. If present, NCBI Taxon should be always listed as "ncbiTaxon" preferably with a purl. The rank of this ID should be species.

MIAPPE V1.1 (DM-42) Organism - An identifier for the organism at the species level. Use of the NCBI taxon ID is recommended.

types.name: GermplasmAttribute
types.description: The Trait-Method-Scale definition for a variable, specifically variables related to Germplasm. Similar to an ObservationVariable, but related to a Germplasm instead of an ObservationUnit

fields.name: additionalInfo
fields.description: A free space containing any additional information related to a particular object. A data source may provide any JSON object, unrestricted by the BrAPI specification.

fields.name: commonCropName
fields.description: Crop name (examples: "Maize", "Wheat")

fields.name: contextOfUse
fields.description: Indication of how trait is routinely used. (examples: ["Trial evaluation", "Nursery evaluation"])

fields.name: defaultValue
fields.description: Variable default value. (examples: "red", "2.3", etc.)

fields.name: documentationURL
fields.description: A URL to the human readable documentation of an object

fields.name: externalReferences
fields.description: An array of external reference ids. These are references to this piece of data in an external system. Could be a simple string or a URI.

fields.name: growthStage
fields.description: Growth stage at which measurement is made (examples: "flowering")

fields.name: institution
fields.description: Name of institution submitting the variable

fields.name: language
fields.description: 2 letter ISO 639-1 code for the language of submission of the variable.

fields.name: methodDbIds
fields.description:
A description of the way an Observation should be collected.
For example, an ObservationVariable might be defined with a Trait of "plant height", a Scale of "meters", and a Method of "tape measure". This variable would be distinct from a variable with the Method "estimation" or "drone image processing".

fields.name: ontologyReference
fields.description:
MIAPPE V1.1

(DM-85) Variable accession number - Accession number of the variable in the Crop Ontology

(DM-87) Trait accession number - Accession number of the trait in a suitable controlled vocabulary (Crop Ontology, Trait Ontology).

(DM-89) Method accession number - Accession number of the method in a suitable controlled vocabulary (Crop Ontology, Trait Ontology).

(DM-93) Scale accession number - Accession number of the scale in a suitable controlled vocabulary (Crop Ontology).

fields.name: scaleDbIds
fields.description:
A Scale describes the units and acceptable values for an ObservationVariable.
For example, an ObservationVariable might be defined with a Trait of "plant height", a Scale of "meters", and a Method of "tape measure". This variable would be distinct from a variable with the Scale "inches" or "pixels".

fields.name: scientist
fields.description: Name of scientist submitting the variable.

fields.name: status
fields.description: Variable status. (examples: "recommended", "obsolete", "legacy", etc.)

fields.name: submissionTimestamp
fields.description: Timestamp when the Variable was added (ISO 8601)

fields.name: synonyms
fields.description: Other variable names

fields.name: traitDbIds
fields.description:
A Trait describes what property is being observed.
For example, an ObservationVariable might be defined with a Trait of "plant height", a Scale of "meters", and a Method of "tape measure". This variable would be distinct from a variable with the Trait "Leaf length" or "Flower height".

fields.name: attributeCategory
fields.description: General category for the attribute. very similar to Trait class.

fields.name: attributeDbId
fields.description: The ID which uniquely identifies this attribute within the given database server

fields.name: attributeName
fields.description: A human readable name for this attribute

fields.name: attributePUI
fields.description: The Permanent Unique Identifier of an Attribute, usually in the form of a URI

fields.name: attributeDescription
fields.description: A human readable description of this attribute

fields.name: attributeValueDbId
fields.description: attributeValues

inputFields.name: method
inputFields.description:
A description of the way an Observation should be collected.
For example, an ObservationVariable might be defined with a Trait of "plant height", a Scale of "meters", and a Method of "tape measure". This variable would be distinct from a variable with the Method "estimation" or "drone image processing".

inputFields.name: ontologyReference
inputFields.description:
MIAPPE V1.1

(DM-85) Variable accession number - Accession number of the variable in the Crop Ontology

(DM-87) Trait accession number - Accession number of the trait in a suitable controlled vocabulary (Crop Ontology, Trait Ontology).

(DM-89) Method accession number - Accession number of the method in a suitable controlled vocabulary (Crop Ontology, Trait Ontology).

(DM-93) Scale accession number - Accession number of the scale in a suitable controlled vocabulary (Crop Ontology).

inputFields.name: scale
inputFields.description:
A Scale describes the units and acceptable values for an ObservationVariable.
For example, an ObservationVariable might be defined with a Trait of "plant height", a Scale of "meters", and a Method of "tape measure". This variable would be distinct from a variable with the Scale "inches" or "pixels".

inputFields.name: status

inputFields.name: submissionTimestamp

inputFields.name: synonyms

inputFields.name: trait
inputFields.description:
A Trait describes what property is being observed.
For example, an ObservationVariable might be defined with a Trait of "plant height", a Scale of "meters", and a Method of "tape measure". This variable would be distinct from a variable with the Trait "Leaf length" or "Flower height".

inputFields.name: commonCropNames
inputFields.description:
The BrAPI Common Crop Name is the simple, generalized, widely accepted name of the organism being researched. It is most often used in multi-crop systems where digital resources need to be divided at a high level. Things like 'Maize', 'Wheat', and 'Rice' are examples of common crop names.

Use this parameter to only return results associated with the given crops. 

Use `GET /commoncropnames` to find the list of available crops on a server.

fields.name: parentType
fields.description:
The type of parent used during crossing. Accepted values for this field are 'MALE', 'FEMALE', 'SELF', 'POPULATION', and 'CLONAL'. 

In a pedigree record, the 'parentType' describes each parent of a particular germplasm. 

In a progeny record, the 'parentType' is used to describe how this germplasm was crossed to generate a particular progeny. 
For example, given a record for germplasm A, having a progeny B and C. The 'parentType' field for progeny B item refers 
to the 'parentType' of A toward B. The 'parentType' field for progeny C item refers to the 'parentType' of A toward C.
In this way, A could be a male parent to B, but a female parent to C.

types.name: GermplasmInput
types.description: The conceptual identifiers and metadata describing a genetically unique organism that is noteworthy in some way. Depending on context, a Germplasm might be synonymous with Accession, Line, or Genotype. Note that Germplasm is conceptual data, not necessarily associated to a real physical object, so Seed/Inventory Lots and Observation Units become physical instantiations of a particular Germplasm. Note a Germplasm is unique and noteworthy, so a Cross may or may not create a new Germplasm, since not every Cross is unique or noteworthy.

inputFields.name: accessionNumber
inputFields.description:
The unique identifier for a material or germplasm within a genebank

MCPD (v2.1) (ACCENUMB) 2. This is the unique identifier for accessions within a genebank, and is assigned when a sample is entered into the genebank collection (e.g. "PI 113869").

inputFields.name: acquisitionDate
inputFields.description:
The date a material or germplasm was acquired by the genebank 

MCPD (v2.1) (ACQDATE) 12. Date on which the accession entered the collection [YYYYMMDD] where YYYY is the year, MM is the month and DD is the day. Missing data (MM or DD) should be indicated with hyphens or "00" [double zero].

inputFields.name: additionalInfo
inputFields.description: A free space containing any additional information related to a particular object. A data source may provide any JSON object, unrestricted by the BrAPI specification.

inputFields.name: biologicalStatusOfAccessionCode
inputFields.description:
MCPD (v2.1) (SAMPSTAT) 19. The coding scheme proposed can be used at 3 different levels of detail: either by using the general codes such as 100, 200, 300, 400, or by using the more specific codes such as 110, 120, etc. 

100) Wild 
110) Natural 
120) Semi-natural/wild 
130) Semi-natural/sown 
200) Weedy 
300) Traditional cultivar/landrace 
400) Breeding/research material 
410) Breeders line 
411) Synthetic population 
412) Hybrid 
413) Founder stock/base population 
414) Inbred line (parent of hybrid cultivar) 
415) Segregating population 
416) Clonal selection 
420) Genetic stock 
421) Mutant (e.g. induced/insertion mutants, tilling populations) 
422) Cytogenetic stocks (e.g. chromosome addition/substitution, aneuploids,  amphiploids) 
423) Other genetic stocks (e.g. mapping populations) 
500) Advanced or improved cultivar (conventional breeding methods) 
600) GMO (by genetic engineering) 
999) Other (Elaborate in REMARKS field)

inputFields.name: biologicalStatusOfAccessionDescription
inputFields.description: Supplemental text description for 'biologicalStatusOfAccessionCode'

inputFields.name: breedingMethod
inputFields.description: The unique identifier for the breeding method used to create this germplasm

inputFields.name: collection
inputFields.description: A specific panel/collection/population name this germplasm belongs to.

inputFields.name: commonCropName
inputFields.description:
Common name for the crop 

MCPD (v2.1) (CROPNAME) 10. Common name of the crop. Example: "malting barley", "mas".

inputFields.name: countryOfOriginCode
inputFields.description:
3-letter ISO 3166-1 code of the country in which the sample was originally collected 

MCPD (v2.1) (ORIGCTY) 13. 3-letter ISO 3166-1 code of the country in which the sample was originally collected (e.g. landrace, crop wild relative, farmers variety), bred or selected (breeding lines, GMOs, segregating populations, hybrids, modern cultivars, etc.). Note- Descriptors 14 to 16 below should be completed accordingly only if it was "collected".

inputFields.name: genus
inputFields.description:
Genus name for taxon. Initial uppercase letter required.

MCPD (v2.1) (GENUS) 5. Genus name for taxon. Initial uppercase letter required.

MIAPPE V1.1 (DM-43) Genus - Genus name for the organism under study, according to standard scientific nomenclature.

inputFields.name: germplasmDbId
inputFields.description:
The ID which uniquely identifies a germplasm within the given database server
MIAPPE V1.1 (DM-41) Biological material ID - Code used to identify the biological material in the data file. Should be unique within the Investigation. Can correspond to experimental plant ID, inventory lot ID, etc. This material identification is different from a BiosampleID which corresponds to Observation Unit or Samples sections below.

inputFields.name: germplasmName
inputFields.description:
Name of the germplasm. It can be the preferred name and does not have to be unique.

MCPD (v2.1) (ACCENAME) 11. Either a registered or other designation given to the material received, other than the donors accession number (23) or collecting number (3). First letter uppercase. Multiple names are separated by a semicolon without space.

inputFields.name: germplasmOrigin
inputFields.description: Information for material (orchard, natural sites, ...). Geographic identification of the plants from which seeds or cutting have been taken to produce that germplasm.

inputFields.name: germplasmPUI
inputFields.description:
The Permanent Unique Identifier which represents a germplasm

MIAPPE V1.1 (DM-41) Biological material ID - Code used to identify the biological material in the data file. Should be unique within the Investigation. Can correspond to experimental plant ID, inventory lot ID, etc This material identification is different from a BiosampleID which corresponds to Observation Unit or Samples sections below.

MIAPPE V1.1 (DM-51) Material source DOI - Digital Object Identifier (DOI) of the material source

MCPD (v2.1) (PUID) 0. Any persistent, unique identifier assigned to the accession so it can be unambiguously referenced at the global level and the information associated with it harvested through automated means. Report one PUID for each accession. The Secretariat of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture (PGRFA) is facilitating the assignment of a persistent unique identifier (PUID), in the form of a DOI, to PGRFA at the accession level. Genebanks not applying a true PUID to their accessions should use, and request recipients to use, the concatenation of INSTCODE, ACCENUMB, and GENUS as a globally unique identifier similar in most respects to the PUID whenever they exchange information on accessions with third parties.

inputFields.name: germplasmPreprocessing
inputFields.description: Description of any process or treatment applied uniformly to the germplasm, prior to the study itself. Can be provided as free text or as an accession number from a suitable controlled vocabulary.

inputFields.name: instituteCode
inputFields.description:
The code for the institute that maintains the material. 

MCPD (v2.1) (INSTCODE) 1. FAO WIEWS code of the institute where the accession is maintained. The codes consist of the 3-letter ISO 3166 country code of the country where the institute is located plus a number (e.g. PER001). The current set of institute codes is available from http://www.fao.org/wiews. For those institutes not yet having an FAO Code, or for those with "obsolete" codes, see "Common formatting rules (v)".

inputFields.name: instituteName
inputFields.description: The name of the institute that maintains the material

inputFields.name: pedigree
inputFields.description:
The cross name and optional selection history.

MCPD (v2.1) (ANCEST) 20. Information about either pedigree or other description of ancestral information (e.g. parent variety in case of mutant or selection). For example a pedigree 'Hanna/7*Atlas//Turk/8*Atlas' or a description 'mutation found in Hanna', 'selection from Irene' or 'cross involving amongst others Hanna and Irene'.

inputFields.name: seedSource
inputFields.description:
An identifier for the source of the biological material
MIAPPE V1.1 (DM-50) Material source ID (Holding institute/stock centre, accession) - An identifier for the source of the biological material, in the form of a key-value pair comprising the name/identifier of the repository from which the material was sourced plus the accession number of the repository for that material. Where an accession number has not been assigned, but the material has been derived from the crossing of known accessions, the material can be defined as follows: "mother_accession X father_accession", or, if father is unknown, as "mother_accession X UNKNOWN". For in situ material, the region of provenance may be used when an accession is not available.

inputFields.name: seedSourceDescription
inputFields.description:
Description of the material source

MIAPPE V1.1 (DM-56) Material source description - Description of the material source

inputFields.name: species
inputFields.description:
Specific epithet portion of the scientific name in lowercase letters.

MCPD (v2.1) (SPECIES) 6. Specific epithet portion of the scientific name in lowercase letters. Only the following abbreviation is allowed: "sp." 

MIAPPE V1.1 (DM-44) Species - Species name (formally: specific epithet) for the organism under study, according to standard scientific nomenclature.

inputFields.name: speciesAuthority
inputFields.description:
The authority organization responsible for tracking and maintaining the species name 

MCPD (v2.1) (SPAUTHOR) 7. Provide the authority for the species name.

inputFields.name: storageTypes
inputFields.description: The type of storage this germplasm is kept in at a genebank.

inputFields.name: subtaxa
inputFields.description:
Subtaxon can be used to store any additional taxonomic identifier.

MCPD (v2.1) (SUBTAXA) 8. Subtaxon can be used to store any additional taxonomic identifier. The following abbreviations are allowed: "subsp." (for subspecies); "convar." (for convariety); "var." (for variety); "f." (for form); "Group" (for "cultivar group").

MIAPPE V1.1 (DM-44) Infraspecific name - Name of any subtaxa level, including variety, crossing name, etc. It can be used to store any additional taxonomic identifier. Either free text description or key-value pair list format (the key is the name of the rank and the value is the value of  the rank). Ranks can be among the following terms: subspecies, cultivar, variety, subvariety, convariety, group, subgroup, hybrid, line, form, subform. For MCPD compliance, the following abbreviations are allowed: subsp. (subspecies); convar. (convariety); var. (variety); f. (form); Group (cultivar group).

inputFields.name: subtaxaAuthority
inputFields.description:
The authority organization responsible for tracking and maintaining the subtaxon information

MCPD (v2.1) (SUBTAUTHOR) 9. Provide the subtaxon authority at the most detailed taxonomic level.

inputFields.name: synonyms
inputFields.description:
List of alternative names or IDs used to reference this germplasm

MCPD (v2.1) (OTHERNUMB) 24. Any other identifiers known to exist in other collections for this accession. Use the following format: INSTCODE:ACCENUMB;INSTCODE:identifier;INSTCODE and identifier are separated by a colon without space. Pairs of INSTCODE and identifier are separated by a semicolon without space. When the institute is not known, the identifier should be preceded by a colon.

inputFields.name: taxonIds
inputFields.description:
The list of IDs for this SPECIES from different sources. If present, NCBI Taxon should be always listed as "ncbiTaxon" preferably with a purl. The rank of this ID should be species.

MIAPPE V1.1 (DM-42) Organism - An identifier for the organism at the species level. Use of the NCBI taxon ID is recommended.

fields.name: imageLocation
fields.description:
One geometry as defined by GeoJSON (RFC 7946). All coordinates are decimal values on the WGS84 geographic coordinate reference system.

Copied from RFC 7946 Section 3.1.1

A position is an array of numbers. There MUST be two or more elements. The first two elements are longitude and latitude, or
easting and northing, precisely in that order and using decimal numbers. Altitude or elevation MAY be included as an optional third element.

types.name: Location
types.description: A geographic Location on earth. This is usually used to describe the general area where an experiment took place. For example, a natural site, an experimental field, a greenhouse, a phenotyping facility, etc.

fields.name: abbreviation
fields.description: A shortened version of the human readable name for a Location

fields.name: additionalInfo
fields.description: A free space containing any additional information related to a particular object. A data source may provide any JSON object, unrestricted by the BrAPI specification.

fields.name: coordinateDescription
fields.description: Describes the precision and landmarks of the coordinate values used for a Location. (ex. the site, the nearest town, a 10 kilometers radius circle, +/- 20 meters, etc)

fields.name: coordinateUncertainty
fields.description: Uncertainty associated with the coordinates in meters. Leave the value empty if the uncertainty is unknown.

fields.name: coordinates
fields.description:
One geometry as defined by GeoJSON (RFC 7946). All coordinates are decimal values on the WGS84 geographic coordinate reference system.

Copied from RFC 7946 Section 3.1.1

A position is an array of numbers. There MUST be two or more elements. The first two elements are longitude and latitude, or
easting and northing, precisely in that order and using decimal numbers. Altitude or elevation MAY be included as an optional third element.

fields.name: countryCode
fields.description:
[ISO_3166-1_alpha-3](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_3166-1_alpha-3) spec
MIAPPE V1.1 (DM-17) Geographic location (country) - The country where the experiment took place, either as a full name or preferably as a 2-letter code.'

fields.name: countryName
fields.description:
The full name of the country where a Location is located
MIAPPE V1.1 (DM-17) Geographic location (country) - The country where the experiment took place, either as a full name or preferably as a 2-letter code.

fields.name: documentationURL
fields.description: A URL to the human readable documentation of an object

fields.name: environmentType
fields.description: Describes the general type of environment of a Location. (ex. forest, field, nursery, etc)

fields.name: exposure
fields.description: Describes the level of protection/exposure for things like sun light and wind at a particular Location

fields.name: externalReferences
fields.description: An array of external reference ids. These are references to this piece of data in an external system. Could be a simple string or a URI.

fields.name: instituteAddress
fields.description:
The street address of the institute at a particular Location
MIAPPE V1.1 (DM-16) Contact institution - Name and address of the institution responsible for the study.

fields.name: instituteName
fields.description:
The full name of the institute at a particular Location
MIAPPE V1.1 (DM-16) Contact institution - Name and address of the institution responsible for the study.

fields.name: locationDbId
fields.description: The unique identifier for a Location

fields.name: locationName
fields.description:
A human readable name for a Location
MIAPPE V1.1 (DM-18) Experimental site name - The name of the natural site, experimental field, greenhouse, phenotyping facility, etc. where the experiment took place.

fields.name: locationType
fields.description: A short description of a type of Location (ex. Field Station, Breeding Location, Storage Location, etc)

fields.name: parentLocationDbIds
fields.description:
The unique identifier for a Location
The Parent Location defines the encompassing Location that a smaller Location belongs to. For example, an Institution might have multiple Field Stations inside it and each Field Station might have multiple Fields.

fields.name: siteStatus
fields.description: Description of the accessibility of the location (ex. Public, Private)

fields.name: slope
fields.description: Describes the approximate slope (height/distance) of a Location.

fields.name: topography
fields.description: Describes the topography of the land at a Location. (ex. Plateau, Cirque, Hill, Valley, etc)

When possible, these field names and abbreviations should follow the VCF standard

types.name: Method
types.description:
A description of the way an Observation should be collected.
For example, an ObservationVariable might be defined with a Trait of "plant height", a Scale of "meters", and a Method of "tape measure". This variable would be distinct from a variable with the Method "estimation" or "drone image processing".

fields.name: additionalInfo
fields.description: A free space containing any additional information related to a particular object. A data source may provide any JSON object, unrestricted by the BrAPI specification.

fields.name: bibliographicalReference
fields.description:
Bibliographical reference describing the method.
MIAPPE V1.1 (DM-91) Reference associated to the method - URI/DOI of reference describing the method.

fields.name: description
fields.description:
Method description
MIAPPE V1.1 (DM-90) Method description - Textual description of the method, which may extend a method defined in an external reference with specific parameters, e.g. growth stage, inoculation precise organ (leaf number)

fields.name: externalReferences
fields.description: An array of external reference ids. These are references to this piece of data in an external system. Could be a simple string or a URI.

fields.name: formula
fields.description: For computational methods i.e., when the method consists in assessing the trait by computing measurements, write the generic formula used for the calculation

fields.name: methodClass
fields.description: Method class (examples: "Measurement", "Counting", "Estimation", "Computation", etc.)

fields.name: methodDbId
fields.description: Method unique identifier

fields.name: methodName
fields.description:
Human readable name for the method
MIAPPE V1.1 (DM-88) Method Name of the method of observation

fields.name: methodPUI
fields.description: The Permanent Unique Identifier of a Method, usually in the form of a URI

fields.name: ontologyReference
fields.description:
MIAPPE V1.1

(DM-85) Variable accession number - Accession number of the variable in the Crop Ontology

(DM-87) Trait accession number - Accession number of the trait in a suitable controlled vocabulary (Crop Ontology, Trait Ontology).

(DM-89) Method accession number - Accession number of the method in a suitable controlled vocabulary (Crop Ontology, Trait Ontology).

(DM-93) Scale accession number - Accession number of the scale in a suitable controlled vocabulary (Crop Ontology).

types.name: MethodInput
types.description:
A description of the way an Observation should be collected.
For example, an ObservationVariable might be defined with a Trait of "plant height", a Scale of "meters", and a Method of "tape measure". This variable would be distinct from a variable with the Method "estimation" or "drone image processing".

inputFields.name: additionalInfo
inputFields.description: A free space containing any additional information related to a particular object. A data source may provide any JSON object, unrestricted by the BrAPI specification.

inputFields.name: bibliographicalReference
inputFields.description:
Bibliographical reference describing the method.
MIAPPE V1.1 (DM-91) Reference associated to the method - URI/DOI of reference describing the method.

inputFields.name: description
inputFields.description:
Method description
MIAPPE V1.1 (DM-90) Method description - Textual description of the method, which may extend a method defined in an external reference with specific parameters, e.g. growth stage, inoculation precise organ (leaf number)

inputFields.name: externalReferences
inputFields.description: Filter by External References

inputFields.name: formula
inputFields.description: For computational methods i.e., when the method consists in assessing the trait by computing measurements, write the generic formula used for the calculation

inputFields.name: methodClass
inputFields.description: Method class (examples: "Measurement", "Counting", "Estimation", "Computation", etc.)

inputFields.name: methodDbId
inputFields.description: Method unique identifier

inputFields.name: methodName
inputFields.description:
Human readable name for the method
MIAPPE V1.1 (DM-88) Method Name of the method of observation

inputFields.name: methodPUI
inputFields.description: The Permanent Unique Identifier of a Method, usually in the form of a URI

inputFields.name: ontologyReference
inputFields.description:
MIAPPE V1.1

(DM-85) Variable accession number - Accession number of the variable in the Crop Ontology

(DM-87) Trait accession number - Accession number of the trait in a suitable controlled vocabulary (Crop Ontology, Trait Ontology).

(DM-89) Method accession number - Accession number of the method in a suitable controlled vocabulary (Crop Ontology, Trait Ontology).

(DM-93) Scale accession number - Accession number of the scale in a suitable controlled vocabulary (Crop Ontology).

inputFields.name: commonCropNames
inputFields.description:
The BrAPI Common Crop Name is the simple, generalized, widely accepted name of the organism being researched. It is most often used in multi-crop systems where digital resources need to be divided at a high level. Things like 'Maize', 'Wheat', and 'Rice' are examples of common crop names.

Use this parameter to only return results associated with the given crops. 

Use `GET /commoncropnames` to find the list of available crops on a server.

inputFields.name: ontologyDbIds
inputFields.description:
The unique identifier for an ontology definition. Use this parameter to filter results based on a specific ontology 

  Use `GET /ontologies` to find the list of available ontologies on a server.

inputFields.name: programDbIds
inputFields.description:
A BrAPI Program represents the high level organization or group who is responsible for conducting trials and studies. Things like Breeding Programs and Funded Projects are considered BrAPI Programs. 

Use this parameter to only return results associated with the given programs. 

Use `GET /programs` to find the list of available programs on a server.

inputFields.name: programNames
inputFields.description:
Use this parameter to only return results associated with the given program names. Program names are not required to be unique.

Use `GET /programs` to find the list of available programs on a server.

inputFields.name: scaleDbIds
inputFields.description: The unique identifier for a method.

inputFields.name: observationVariableDbIds
inputFields.description: The unique identifier for an observation variable.

One geometry as defined by GeoJSON (RFC 7946). All coordinates are decimal values on the WGS84 geographic coordinate reference system.

Copied from RFC 7946 Section 3.1.1

A position is an array of numbers. There MUST be two or more elements. The first two elements are longitude and latitude, or

types.name: ObservationUnitHierarchyLevel
types.description: The exact level and level code of an observation unit. For more information on Observation Levels, please review the Observation Levels documentation. MIAPPE V1.1 DM-71 Observation unit type "Type of observation unit in textual form, usually one of the following: study, block, sub-block, plot, sub-plot, pot, plant. Use of other observation unit types is possible but not recommended. The observation unit type can not be used to indicate sub-plant levels. However, observations can still be made on the sub-plant level, as long as the details are indicated in the associated observed variable (see observed variables). Alternatively, it is possible to use samples for more detailed tracing of sub-plant units, attaching the observations to them instead."

fields.name: levelOrder
fields.description: `levelOrder` defines where that level exists in the hierarchy of levels. `levelOrder`'s lower numbers are at the top of the hierarchy (ie field -> 1) and higher numbers are at the bottom of the hierarchy (ie plant -> 9). For more information on Observation Levels, please review the Observation Levels documentation.

fields.name: levelCode
fields.description:
An ID code or number to represent a real thing that may or may not be an an observation unit.
For example, if the 'levelName' is 'plot', then the 'levelCode' would be the plot number or plot barcode. If this plot is also considered an ObservationUnit, then the appropriate observationUnitDbId should also be recorded.
If the 'levelName' is 'field', then the 'levelCode' might be something like '3' or 'F3' to indicate the third field at a research station.

types.name: ObservationUnitLevelRelationship
types.description: Observation levels indicate the granularity level at which the measurements are taken. `levelName` defines the level, `levelOrder` defines where that level exists in the hierarchy of levels. `levelOrder`s lower numbers are at the top of the hierarchy (ie field > 0) and higher numbers are at the bottom of the hierarchy (ie plant > 6). `levelCode` is an ID code for this level tag. Identify this observation unit by each level of the hierarchy where it exists. For more information on Observation Levels, please review the Observation Levels documentation. **Standard Level Names: study, field, entry, rep, block, sub-block, plot, sub-plot, plant, pot, sample**

inputFields.description: The type of entry for this observation unit. ex. "CHECK", "TEST", "FILLER"

inputFields.name: geoCoordinates
inputFields.description:
One geometry as defined by GeoJSON (RFC 7946). All coordinates are decimal values on the WGS84 geographic coordinate reference system.

Copied from RFC 7946 Section 3.1.1

A position is an array of numbers. There MUST be two or more elements. The first two elements are longitude and latitude, or
easting and northing, precisely in that order and using decimal numbers. Altitude or elevation MAY be included as an optional third element.

inputFields.name: observationLevel
inputFields.description: The exact level and level code of an observation unit. For more information on Observation Levels, please review the Observation Levels documentation. MIAPPE V1.1 DM-71 Observation unit type "Type of observation unit in textual form, usually one of the following: study, block, sub-block, plot, sub-plot, pot, plant. Use of other observation unit types is possible but not recommended. The observation unit type can not be used to indicate sub-plant levels. However, observations can still be made on the sub-plant level, as long as the details are indicated in the associated observed variable (see observed variables). Alternatively, it is possible to use samples for more detailed tracing of sub-plant units, attaching the observations to them instead."

inputFields.name: observationLevelRelationships
inputFields.description: Observation levels indicate the granularity level at which the measurements are taken. `levelName` defines the level, `levelOrder` defines where that level exists in the hierarchy of levels. `levelOrder`s lower numbers are at the top of the hierarchy (ie field > 0) and higher numbers are at the bottom of the hierarchy (ie plant > 6). `levelCode` is an ID code for this level tag. Identify this observation unit by each level of the hierarchy where it exists. For more information on Observation Levels, please review the Observation Levels documentation. **Standard Level Names: study, field, entry, rep, block, sub-block, plot, sub-plot, plant, pot, sample**

types.name: ParentType
types.description:
The type of parent used during crossing. Accepted values for this field are 'MALE', 'FEMALE', 'SELF', 'POPULATION', and 'CLONAL'. 

In a pedigree record, the 'parentType' describes each parent of a particular germplasm. 

In a progeny record, the 'parentType' is used to describe how this germplasm was crossed to generate a particular progeny. 
For example, given a record for germplasm A, having a progeny B and C. The 'parentType' field for progeny B item refers 
to the 'parentType' of A toward B. The 'parentType' field for progeny C item refers to the 'parentType' of A toward C.
In this way, A could be a male parent to B, but a female parent to C.

types.name: PedigreeNode
types.description: A representation of a particular Germplasm within a pedigree tree, and all the links to its parents, siblings, and children. From a list of PedigreeNode objects, a client application should have all the information it needs to draw a pedigree tree visualization, or calculate genetic distances.

fields.name: additionalInfo
fields.description: A free space containing any additional information related to a particular object. A data source may provide any JSON object, unrestricted by the BrAPI specification.

fields.name: breedingMethodDbIds
fields.description: The unique identifier for the breeding method used to create this germplasm

fields.name: crossingProjectDbIds
fields.description: The crossing project used to generate this germplasm

fields.name: crossingYear
fields.description: The year the parents were originally crossed

fields.name: defaultDisplayName
fields.description: Human readable name used for display purposes

fields.name: externalReferences
fields.description: An array of external reference ids. These are references to this piece of data in an external system. Could be a simple string or a URI.

fields.name: familyCode
fields.description: The code representing the family of this germplasm

fields.name: germplasmDbIds
fields.description: The ID which uniquely identifies a germplasm

fields.name: parents
fields.description:
A list of parent germplasm references in the pedigree tree for this germplasm. These represent edges in the tree, connecting to other nodes.
Typically, this array should only have one parent (clonal or self) or two parents (cross). In some special cases, there may be more parents, usually when the exact parent is not known.
If the parameter 'includeParents' is set to false, then this array should be empty, null, or not present in the response.

fields.name: pedigreeNodeDbId
fields.description: The ID which uniquely identifies a pedigree node

fields.name: pedigreeString
fields.description: The string representation of the pedigree for this germplasm in PURDY notation

fields.name: progeny
fields.description:
A list of germplasm references that are direct children of this germplasm. These represent edges in the tree, connecting to other nodes.
The given germplasm could have a large number of progeny, across a number of different breeding methods. The 'parentType' shows the type of parent this germplasm is to each of the child germplasm references.
If the parameter 'includeProgeny' is set to false, then this array should be empty, null, or not present in the response.

fields.name: siblingDbId
fields.description:
A list of sibling germplasm references in the pedigree tree for this germplasm. These represent edges in the tree, connecting to other nodes.
Siblings share at least one parent with the given germplasm.
If the parameter 'includeSiblings' is set to false, then this array should be empty, null, or not present in the response.

types.name: PedigreeNodeInput
types.description: A representation of a particular Germplasm within a pedigree tree, and all the links to its parents, siblings, and children. From a list of PedigreeNode objects, a client application should have all the information it needs to draw a pedigree tree visualization, or calculate genetic distances.

inputFields.name: additionalInfo
inputFields.description: A free space containing any additional information related to a particular object. A data source may provide any JSON object, unrestricted by the BrAPI specification.

inputFields.name: breedingMethod
inputFields.description: The unique identifier for the breeding method used to create this germplasm

inputFields.name: crossingProject
inputFields.description: The crossing project used to generate this germplasm

inputFields.name: crossingYear
inputFields.description: The year the parents were originally crossed

inputFields.name: defaultDisplayName
inputFields.description: Human readable name used for display purposes

inputFields.name: externalReferences
inputFields.description: Filter by External References

inputFields.name: familyCode
inputFields.description: The code representing the family of this germplasm

inputFields.name: germplasm
inputFields.description: The ID which uniquely identifies a germplasm

inputFields.name: parents
inputFields.description:
A list of parent germplasm references in the pedigree tree for this germplasm. These represent edges in the tree, connecting to other nodes.
Typically, this array should only have one parent (clonal or self) or two parents (cross). In some special cases, there may be more parents, usually when the exact parent is not known.
If the parameter 'includeParents' is set to false, then this array should be empty, null, or not present in the response.

inputFields.name: pedigreeNodeDbId
inputFields.description: The ID which uniquely identifies a pedigree node

inputFields.name: pedigreeString
inputFields.description: The string representation of the pedigree for this germplasm in PURDY notation

inputFields.name: progeny
inputFields.description:
A list of germplasm references that are direct children of this germplasm. These represent edges in the tree, connecting to other nodes.
The given germplasm could have a large number of progeny, across a number of different breeding methods. The 'parentType' shows the type of parent this germplasm is to each of the child germplasm references.
If the parameter 'includeProgeny' is set to false, then this array should be empty, null, or not present in the response.

inputFields.name: siblings
inputFields.description:
A list of sibling germplasm references in the pedigree tree for this germplasm. These represent edges in the tree, connecting to other nodes.
Siblings share at least one parent with the given germplasm.
If the parameter 'includeSiblings' is set to false, then this array should be empty, null, or not present in the response.

inputFields.name: commonCropNames
inputFields.description:
The BrAPI Common Crop Name is the simple, generalized, widely accepted name of the organism being researched. It is most often used in multi-crop systems where digital resources need to be divided at a high level. Things like 'Maize', 'Wheat', and 'Rice' are examples of common crop names.

Use this parameter to only return results associated with the given crops. 

Use `GET /commoncropnames` to find the list of available crops on a server.

The code for the institute that maintains the material.
MCPD (v2.1) (INSTCODE) 1. FAO WIEWS code of the institute where the accession is maintained. The codes consist of the 3-letter ISO 3166 country code of the country where the institute is located plus a number (e.g. PER001). The current set of institute codes is available from http://www.fao.org/wiews. For those institutes not yet having an FAO Code, or for those with "obsolete" codes, see "Common formatting rules (v)".

types.name: PositionCoordinateType
types.description:
The type of positional coordinate. Must be one of the following values 

LONGITUDE - ISO 6709 standard, WGS84 geodetic datum. See 'Location Coordinate Encoding' for details 

LATITUDE - ISO 6709 standard, WGS84 geodetic datum. See 'Location Coordinate Encoding' for details 

PLANTED_ROW - The physical planted row number 

PLANTED_INDIVIDUAL - The physical counted number, could be independent or within a planted row 

GRID_ROW - The row index number of a square grid overlay 

GRID_COL - The column index number of a square grid overlay 

MEASURED_ROW - The distance in meters from a defined 0-th row 

MEASURED_COL - The distance in meters from a defined 0-th column

types.name: Reference
types.description: A `Reference` is a canonical assembled contig, intended to act as a reference coordinate space for other genomic annotations. A single `Reference` might represent the human chromosome 1, for instance. `References` are designed to be immutable.

fields.name: additionalInfo
fields.description: A free space containing any additional information related to a particular object. A data source may provide any JSON object, unrestricted by the BrAPI specification.

fields.name: commonCropName
fields.description: Common name for the crop

fields.name: externalReferences
fields.description: An array of external reference ids. These are references to this piece of data in an external system. Could be a simple string or a URI.

fields.name: isDerived
fields.description: A sequence X is said to be derived from source sequence Y, if X and Y are of the same length and the per-base sequence divergence at A/C/G/T bases is sufficiently small. Two sequences derived from the same official sequence share the same coordinates and annotations, and can be replaced with the official sequence for certain use cases.

fields.name: length
fields.description: The length of this `Reference` sequence.

fields.name: md5checksum
fields.description: The MD5 checksum uniquely representing this `Reference` as a lower-case hexadecimal string, calculated as the MD5 of the upper-case sequence excluding all whitespace characters (this is equivalent to SQ:M5 in SAM).

fields.name: referenceDbId
fields.description: The unique identifier for a `Reference`

fields.name: referenceName
fields.description: The human readable name of a `Reference` within a `ReferenceSet`.

fields.name: referenceSetDbIds
fields.description: The unique identifier for a `ReferenceSet`

fields.name: sourceAccessions
fields.description: All known corresponding accession IDs in INSDC (GenBank/ENA/DDBJ) which must include a version number, e.g. `GCF_000001405.26`.

fields.name: sourceDivergence
fields.description: The `sourceDivergence` is the fraction of non-indel bases that do not match the `Reference` this message was derived from.

fields.name: sourceGermplasmDbId
fields.description: All known corresponding Germplasm

fields.name: sourceURI
fields.description: The URI from which the sequence was obtained. Specifies a FASTA format file/string with one name, sequence pair. In most cases, clients should call the `getReferenceBases()` method to obtain sequence bases for a `Reference` instead of attempting to retrieve this URI.

fields.name: species
fields.description: An ontology term describing an attribute.

fields.name: variantDbId
fields.description: variants

types.name: ReferenceSet
types.description: A `ReferenceSet` is a set of `Reference` s which typically comprise a reference assembly, such as `GRCH_38`. A `ReferenceSet` defines a common coordinate space for comparing reference-aligned experimental data.

fields.name: additionalInfo
fields.description: A free space containing any additional information related to a particular object. A data source may provide any JSON object, unrestricted by the BrAPI specification.

fields.name: assemblyPUI
fields.description: The remaining information is about the source of the sequences Public id of this reference set, such as `GRCH_37`.

fields.name: commonCropName
fields.description: Common name for the crop

fields.name: description
fields.description: Optional free text description of this reference set.

fields.name: externalReferences
fields.description: An array of external reference ids. These are references to this piece of data in an external system. Could be a simple string or a URI.

fields.name: isDerived
fields.description: A reference set may be derived from a source if it contains additional sequences, or some of the sequences within it are derived (see the definition of `isDerived` in `Reference`).

fields.name: md5checksum
fields.description:
Order-independent MD5 checksum which identifies this `ReferenceSet`.

To compute this checksum, make a list of `Reference.md5checksum` for all
`Reference` s in this set. Then sort that list, and take the MD5 hash of
all the strings concatenated together. Express the hash as a lower-case
hexadecimal string.

fields.name: referenceSetDbId
fields.description: The unique identifier for a ReferenceSet

fields.name: referenceSetName
fields.description: The human readable name of a ReferenceSet

fields.name: sourceAccessions
fields.description: All known corresponding accession IDs in INSDC (GenBank/ENA/DDBJ) ideally with a version number, e.g. `NC_000001.11`.

fields.name: sourceGermplasmDbId
fields.description: All known corresponding Germplasm

fields.name: sourceURI
fields.description: Specifies a FASTA format file/string.

fields.name: species
fields.description: An ontology term describing an attribute.

fields.description: references

inputFields.name: commonCropNames
inputFields.description:
The BrAPI Common Crop Name is the simple, generalized, widely accepted name of the organism being researched. It is most often used in multi-crop systems where digital resources need to be divided at a high level. Things like 'Maize', 'Wheat', and 'Rice' are examples of common crop names.

Use this parameter to only return results associated with the given crops. 

Use `GET /commoncropnames` to find the list of available crops on a server.

inputFields.name: germplasmNames
inputFields.description: List of human readable names to identify germplasm to search for

A BrAPI Program represents the high level organization or group who is responsible for conducting trials and studies. Things like Breeding Programs and Funded Projects are considered BrAPI Programs. 

Use this parameter to only return results associated with the given programs. 

Use `GET /programs` to find the list of available programs on a server.

Use `GET /programs` to find the list of available programs on a server.
